pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The goal of this EPSCoR Track II project was to create the Dakota Bioconversion Consortium (DakotaBioCon) through an interstate collaboration between four research universities in South Dakota and North Dakota. DakotaBioCon’s research goal was to develop biochemical and chemical processes that would depolymerize lignin (a major component of plants) into the monomers that comprise it. These monomers could serve as a renewable source of raw materials that could substitute for high-value, petroleum-derived chemicals in processes that produce industrial chemicals, resins and polymers. Its infrastructure goal was to build the long-term collaborative infrastructure necessary to study novel pathways for sustainable production of high-value lignin-derived chemical raw materials.

Intellectual Merit: Research Outcomes

Biochemical Lignin Depolymerization: Microbially-driven depolymerization studies demonstrated the ability to convert lignin into specific monomers using laccase with methyl syringate as a mediator. A significant yield of vanillin, up to 40%, was obtained. The laccase from Trametes versicolor produced the highest yields. A new approach to biochemical depolymerization was developed that solubilized lignin in dimethyl sulfoxide followed by the application of immobilized fungal cultures to significant enhance yields.

Chemical Lignin Depolymerization: Non-catalytic decomposition appears to be at least as effective as catalytic decomposition for primary bond cleavage of lignin.  A non-catalytic system avoids the problems with coke formation that limits the effectiveness of the catalytic approaches the program considered. A critical discovery that the β–O-4 linkage in lignin can be converted to a vinyl ether structure which is much harder to cleave. Avoiding the use of basic condition is found to be the key to effective decomposition of lignin.

Chemical pretreatment in combination with biodepolymerization showed that the addition of non-aqueous protic solvents, e.g., methanol, is essential for an efficient conversion of lignin into phenolic monomers.

Production of Polymers and Resins from Lignin: A wide variety of polymers based on three different starting materials obtained from lignin: eugenol, guaiacol, and syringol, were synthesized both as homopolymers and co-polymers. The use of vanillin in several different types of thermosetting polymer systems was demonstrated.

A novel method useful for the direct functionalization of lignin to produce liquid products that can be cured was developed. Co-polymers were converted to novel amphiphilic fouling-release coatings designed to mitigate issues of biofouling of ship hulls and also to epoxy resins by epoxidation of allylic double bonds present in the EEVE-based repeat units. These epoxy-functional polymers were used to produce coatings by curing with multifunctional amines and characterized and compared to benchmark coatings.

A novel process for the direct functionalization of lignin with acetoacetate groups to yield a liquid reactive resin was investigated. The discovery that lignin is soluble in low molecular weight polyols enabled development of a process coupling dissolution in the diol and acetoacetylation yielding functionalized lignin with an acetoacetylated diluent. The resulting resins were cross-linked using melamine-formaldehyde resins to form cured coatings. This process has been extended to other functional groups.

Life-Cycle Analysis (LCA) to Assess Sustainability: The most promising process for lignin decomposition to monomer used in LCA modeling consisted of the following parameters: 0.1g of lignin processed with 10-min residence at 200°C using a H2O:CO2 ratio of 1:1 and a NiO catalyst. The electricity used for maintaining operational conditions during depolymerization was a major impact contributor. Dichloromethane solvent use was also a significant life cycle impact contributor. This scenario’s promise was primarily due to the low reaction temperature and its corresponding energy consumption. Lower temperature reactions had lower environmental impact with comparable productivity. The use of lower-impact solvents (such as ethyl acetate instead of dichloromethane) and non-toxic catalysts (such as CO2) also reduced environmental impact. 

Broader Impact Outcomes

DakotaBioCon provided research opportunities and research training to graduate and undergraduate students. A variety of workshops introduced the concepts of Green Chemistry, sustainability, and bioprocessing to K-12 and tribal college students.

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2016
Modified by: James A Rice
